reviews.review_msg: Quizzes were too broad which made it really difficult to study for. The persuasive paper is 40% of your mark so spend a lot of time on that. He's a pretty funny professor though.

Mike grades on a curve. I did well on the paper which meant I did well in the class. The quizzes were tough and the average was low, but the curve boosted me. Attend the lectures and read the textbook and youll get a good grade. The group project is easy as well.

Lectures are okay, but don't teach you enough to do well in the class. If it wasn't mandatory and graded, I'd say stay home and read the text book. Honestly, I got the second highest mark on the midterm by just binge-reading the textbook in the week before. The average was about half of my grade. Decent teacher, but the text is more useful.

The first 'Group Project' class of engineering. However... The persuasive paper is worth 40% of your grade. Start thinking about what you want to write early, and FOLLOW THE RUBRIC. Seriously. The paper's worth double the entire group project.

Nothing notable about lectures, they were generally straightforward and easy to follow. Quizzes are fairly simple and follow common sense. Group project grade depends mostly on your TA rather than Mike.

Mike is funny and the overall class is not bad, make sure to do practice quizzes as he uses a lot of old questions for his quizzes. also make sure to take good notes because the lecture slides he posts aren't very helpful by itself if you are trying to study

Lecture slides are mostly just pictures and quizzes are very reliant on what he says in class. Worth mentioning that half of the lectures in the term were guest lectures. Gives good feedback and does try to remember a lot of students' names. Engaging and very reachable and responsive, generous too.
Enjoyed my semester with him. Make sure you do the previous years quizzes, almost the exact same as the ones in class (Same questions).

Mike Hegedus is a very nice man, he is funny and his lectures are entertaining. The lectures involve history of engineering and society, with guest lectures on topics such as "Space engineering" and "Military engineering". The labs are where you work with your group to design and build an engineering project that solves a problem. Study for quizes!

Pay attention and take lots of notes. Much of the quiz content is not on the slides so you must go off what he is saying. For the group project go to his office hours often to discuss things with him, he is good at helping with problems you may encounter. Overall a nice and fair professor.

Mike is a cool guy to be around. His subject isn't super interesting at times, but just make sure to take notes anyway because you'll need it to study for quizzes. The practice quizzes he posts don't have answer keys attached to them, so make detailed notes. It's easy to mess up on his quizzes. He's a pretty nice guy to talk to, and is funny too.

Mike is awesome. Although he can seem very rough around the edges and critical, he genuinely cares about his Eng student's success. Come to him for advice and he will always be willing to talk, and he is very accessible outside the class. The lectures cover all material for the quizzes, and as long as you take notes you'll be fine.
He is the most boring person ever. If u have him make sure u bring airpods to class.

Goated professor. Had him for ENSC 100 in my first semester at SFU, he was always helpful and accessible for questions I had about other classes as well. Assignments and lectures were good, and quizzes were pretty difficult, but overall a pretty good course.
Always there to help, even if the assignment isn't from his class lol.
One of the best professors you can have. ENSC 100W was the highlight of my day with Mike.
The only good professor in first year engineering.
Mike Hegedus was a decent professor, but he made some inappropriate comments during a lecture that nauseated me.

Mike is a wonderful prof who truly cares about his students. I actually look forward to his lectures, and they're always the highlight of my day. It should be noted that he does not record his lectures and that attendance is an absolute must.

Mike is honestly really awesome. As a first-year engineering student, he really helped prepare us for the workload, giving us a timeline for when things would get tough (ie, when heavy work load begins). He's always there to talk to, even if its just general engineering stuff, not course related.

Mike is the real og. If anyone talks smack on here about him, I'll be seeing you in the back of a Wendy's. There's not much in this class other than a project and a paper, so if you got a good group you're fine. Mike rocks my socks off, he cares about his students and leaves you teary at the end of the semester. Mike is the best, lest we forgest.

Steve is great. Gave out candy on multiple occasions, and is an all-around good lecturer. Participating in the class is 20% of your grade so show up and comment once every week or so in the discussion boards. Passing this class is not difficult.

The course was largely based around a group project and a paper from a co-requisite class. His "practice tests" use the same questions as his actual tests, so attendance and textbook reading is not mandatory. He is a great professor though who is passionate about engineering and helping students learn.

Excellent speaker and a very nice professor. He wrote the textbook himself, so he remembered everything in the book pretty much. This course was boring since it was about history related things but if you like history, its fine.
Very interesting teacher, and passionate about what he's teaching!
Dr Jones is very interesting to listen to. His accent is very soothing and he has a great sense of humour.  Going to lectures can get boring, but as long as you read the book you'll do fine.
Great and patient professor. Very dedicated man. Quiz difficulty is a little unreasonable but scales appropriately. Applies pressures on students quite fairly as well.
Without a doubt best prof I've had at SFU so far. Lectures are fun, made me love engineering. Take his class even if you're not an engineering major!
My favourite course in the engineering program. I learned so many interesting things in this class. Highly recommended even if you're not in the program
